Introduction

Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are a group of neoplasms characterized by disrupted proliferation and differentiation of myeloid stem cells.  As a result, there is accumulation of dysplastic (ie, abnormal-appearing) cells and impairment of normal hematopoiesis.  Patients have cytopenias and are at risk for transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Pathogenesis and risk factors



The pathogenesis of MDS begins with a genetic mutation in a myeloid stem cell that disrupts its growth and differentiation.  As the myeloid stem cell proliferates, many of the progeny cells undergo apoptosis in the bone marrow (ie, ineffective hematopoiesis), resulting in cytopenias.  Patients therefore develop symptoms related to anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia.  The anemia caused by ineffective hematopoiesis also triggers a physiologic suppression of hepcidin, a hormone that normally suppresses intestinal iron absorption.  Low hepcidin levels cause increased intestinal absorption of iron that can eventually progress to systemic iron overload.



The remaining bone marrow progeny cells that do not undergo apoptosis mature and accumulate as dysplastic cells, further disrupting hematopoiesis of surrounding cells.



Several genetic mutations are associated with MDS.  The most common include:



  • Individual mutations:  Involving genes related to RNA splicing (eg, SF3B1), DNA methylation (eg, DNMT3A), and chromatin modification
  • Chromosomal mutations (eg, deletion of 5q, monosomy 7)


The following factors increase the patient's risk for acquiring one of these genetic mutations:



  • Age >70
  • Previous chemotherapy or radiation therapy
  • Environmental toxin (eg, benzene, tobacco) exposure
  • Inherited genetic conditions (eg, Fanconi anemia, ataxia-telangiectasia)

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of MDS can vary, depending on the progression of disease.  MDS can be an incidental finding on routine laboratory testing in asymptomatic patients.  If present, symptoms are often nonspecific and related to impaired hematopoiesis.  Patients can present with symptoms of anemia (eg, weakness, fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, pallor), neutropenia (eg, recurrent infections), or thrombocytopenia (eg, easy bleeding, bruising, petechiae).  Constitutional symptoms (eg, fever, weight loss, night sweats) can be seen in severe cases or during transformation to AML.  Because significant extramedullary hematopoiesis does not occur in MDS, the physical examination of the spleen and liver in patients is usually unremarkable.

Diagnosis



MDS should be considered in any patient with unexplained cytopenia.  Diagnostic criteria for MDS require:



  • Cytopenia:  Complete blood count typically shows persistent normocytic or macrocytic anemia.  Because erythrocyte production is impaired, the reticulocyte count will be inappropriately low or normal despite significant anemia.  Leukopenia and thrombocytopenia can also occur. 
  • Low blast cell percentage:  Peripheral blood and bone marrow evaluation shows <20% blast cells.


In addition, one of the following must be present:



  • Dysplastic cell morphology: 

    • Peripheral blood smear with dysplastic erythrocytes (eg, ovalomacrocytosis) and dysplastic neutrophils (eg, increased size, decreased number of lobules, hypogranulation) (
      image 1
      ).
    • Bone marrow evaluation with a hypercellular marrow with dysplasia of â‰¥1 cell lines.  Erythroid precursors may show signs of abnormal development, including large size and nuclear lobation/budding.  There may be ring sideroblasts present due to iron accumulation in the mitochondria.  Granulocyte precursors typically show evidence of impaired maturation such as abnormal size, shape of the nucleus, or cytoplasmic granularity. 
  • Characteristic cytogenetic (eg, del[5q]) or molecular features (eg, SF3B1 mutation)

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of MDS includes other conditions that can cause cytopenia and/or dysplasia.

Nonmalignant conditions



  • Nutritional deficiencies (eg, vitamin B12, folate):  These can present with macrocytic anemia with dysplastic changes.  However, neutrophils are typically hypersegmented (
    image 2
    ), not hyposegmented.
  • Medication/toxin exposure:  Certain medications (eg, tacrolimus, isoniazid) are associated with dysplastic changes that are typically reversible on discontinuation of the drug, unlike MDS.
  • Infection:  HIV infection can contribute to cytopenia with dysplasia.  Parvovirus can cause anemia with giant pronormoblasts (
    image 3
    ). 
  • Aplastic anemia:  This condition involves bone marrow failure causing pancytopenia; however, the bone marrow is hypocellular, in contrast to the hypercellularity seen in MDS.

Malignant conditions



  • AML:  Although MDS can transform to AML, AML would have a higher initial percentage of blast cells in the bone marrow (>20%).
  • Myeloproliferative disorders (eg, chronic myeloid leukemia, myelofibrosis):  These clonal disorders are associated with cytopenia.  However, they are typically associated with organomegaly (eg, massive splenomegaly), which is not seen in MDS.  In addition, significant dysplasia is not expected. 
  • Plasma cell disorders (eg, multiple myeloma):  These may present with cytopenia but can be distinguished by cell morphology (eg, increased plasma cells in multiple myeloma) (
    image 4
    ).

Prognosis and management



The prognosis of MDS can vary; factors associated with a poor prognosis include older age at symptom onset, presence of complex cytogenetic abnormalities, severe cytopenias involving multiple cell lines, and higher percentage of blast cells.  Progression to AML also has a poor prognosis as it does not respond well to chemotherapy.  Treatment of MDS is individualized, depending on the patient's symptoms and risk for severe disease, and includes the following:

Supportive care



The supportive care of MDS is based on symptoms related to cytopenias.



  • Anemia:  Red blood cell transfusions may be administered as needed.  Exogenous erythropoietin may be considered if recurrent transfusions are necessary.
  • Thrombocytopenia:  Platelet transfusions may be administered as needed; thrombopoietin receptor agonists may also be considered.


  • Neutropenia:  Empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics should be initiated promptly if infection is suspected.

Disease-modifying treatments



  • Hypomethylating agents (azacitidine, decitabine):  MDS are associated with abnormalities in DNA methylation, and hypomethylating agents inhibit DNA methyltransferase. 
  • Lenalidomide:  This immunomodulatory drug is a derivative of thalidomide.  It targets specific proteins for degradation, causing cell death. 
  • Allogeneic stem cell transplantation:  This is the only potentially curative option for MDS but is generally reserved for younger patients with high-risk disease due to the risk of treatment-related complications.

Summary



Myelodysplastic syndromes are a group of neoplasms characterized by disrupted proliferation and differentiation of myeloid stem cells (
